Figurative Meaning: To be full of excuses or stories; not trustworthy
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to Saturnino Calleja, a famous Spanish editor known for children’s stories; used across Alto Aragón
First Example Sentence: Ye que tiene más cuento que Calleja, no te fiques d’ell.
Second Example Sentence: Cada vegada tien una historia nueva, más cuento que Calleja.
Third Example Sentence: M’ha dito que no puet venir, pero yo creo que tien más cuento que Calleja.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Reflexive verb phrase with pronominal verb (fer-se)
Figurative Meaning: To play dumb or act like you don’t know what’s happening
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Longanizo is a type of sausage in Aragón; idea of being “thick” or slow
First Example Sentence: Quan li pregunten, se fa lo longanizo como si no sabese res.
Second Example Sentence: No te faces lo longanizo, que bien lo sabías.
Third Example Sentence: Se fa lo longanizo cada vegada que toca treballar.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Prepositional verbal phrase with estar + en
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Chorda refers to ‘cord’; expression across Jacetania
First Example Sentence: Lo crío salió ta la carrera estando en chordas.
Second Example Sentence: Me pilloron en chordas y sin poder fer cosa.
Third Example Sentence: Dixió que no entrase porque yera en chordas.

Figurative Meaning: To have a temper or be grumpy
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Estar enfadado o de mal humor
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: ‘Truncho’ in Ribagorza means a grudge or burden
First Example Sentence: Tien un truncho que no se puet ni parlar con ell.
Second Example Sentence: No le digas cosa, que lleva un truncho d’ayeri.
Third Example Sentence: Cada vegada que plou, tiene un truncho tremendo.

Figurative Meaning: To go away angrily or be dismissed
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common in many Iberian languages; also used in Somontano
First Example Sentence: Me'n voy a fer puñetas si isto sigue así.
Second Example Sentence: Lo mandé a fer puñetas porque ya cansaba.
Third Example Sentence: Dixió que quería fer puñetas y marchó de casa.

Figurative Meaning: To be very tired or worn out
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from the exhaustion after a long trek to Huesca
First Example Sentence: Ye d’a uesca de tanto treballar.
Second Example Sentence: No puet fer más, ye d’a uesca.
Third Example Sentence: Viengo d’a uesca y solo quiero dormir.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Verbal phrase with metaphorical object + hyperbole
Figurative Meaning: To mess up completely or make a big mistake
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Used in the Pirineo; ‘corvillo’ is the back of the knee
First Example Sentence: La he clavau hasta lo corvillo con lo informe.
Second Example Sentence: Si la clavas hasta lo corvillo, después no chilles.
Third Example Sentence: Cada vegada que improvise, la clava hasta lo corvillo.

Figurative Meaning: To be ready to react quickly, often too much
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Estar a la defensiva o siempre listo para saltar
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Widely used across Spain and adapted into Aragonese in Graus and Barbastro
First Example Sentence: Siempre ye a la que salta, no se puet charrar tranquilo.
Second Example Sentence: Está a la que salta con tot lo que digo.
Third Example Sentence: No fa falta estar a la que salta, que no t’atacan.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Infinitive verbal phrase with definite article + adjective
Figurative Meaning: To be lazy or deliberately slow in doing something
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Popular in central Aragón, especially in Sobrarbe; 'ronso' refers to someone sluggish
First Example Sentence: Ha feito lo ronso tot lo día sin fer cosa.
Second Example Sentence: No faigas lo ronso y espabila ya.
Third Example Sentence: Lo chiquet sempre fa lo ronso quan toca estudiar.

Idiom (Aragonese): Estar como un tozino en misa
Figurative Meaning: To be completely out of place or clueless
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Estar desubicado / No entender nada del contexto
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Used throughout Hoya de Huesca; humorous jab at pigs being clueless in sacred places
First Example Sentence: Quan charlaban de política, yera como un tozino en misa.
Second Example Sentence: No entiendió ni papa, estaba como un tozino en misa.
Third Example Sentence: Cada vegada que va a clase, pareixe un tozino en misa.
